entry.value: This page will detail the different actions available in Rapid. We will be covering many concepts with actions, but for this page we are focussing on buttons. Each be accompanied by a hint that explains in greater detail what each button does and some more details on how to use the actions.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
Pressing the 'Hide' button will hide the image and pressing the 'Show' button will reveal the image again.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
Pressing this button will trigger the image on the right to show and hide itself, using a single button.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
Pressing the two buttons will slide the text below into view or out of view.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
This text will disappear when the above buttons are pressed.
Pressing this button will cause the text below to show and hide itself, with a single button.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
This text will disappear when the above button is pressed.
Pressing the 'Fade out' button will fade the image out over time and pressing the 'Fade in' button will reveal the image again.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
Similar to the above, this button will fade the image in and out based on the current state of the image.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
Pressing the button will put the focus on the input box to the right.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
The 'Disable input' button will disable the input to the right, putting it into read-only mode. The 'Enable input' button will re-enable the input box.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
The 'Add class' button will apply a Rapid theme style class to the button on the right. The 'Remove class' button will remove this class.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
As with other toggle features in Rapid, the 'Toggle class' button will apply a Rapid theme style class to the button on the right, or remove it, based on the current state of the control.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"

Removes the child classes that are attached to the 'Sample' button on the right. In this case the 'Sample' button is contained within a panel, classed as a parent control. Removing the style classes in this way will clear up any added features to all child controls within the parent.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
Pressing the 'Show dialogue' button will display a dialogue. Dialogues are additional pages that you make in Rapid and then navigate to them.

A more specialist action, the showError action is used to display a default error message if it has been overwritten with anything else in an error action. In the event you want this default error message again then you can use the showError action to have it display once more.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
Activating the clearQueue action will carry out the current process, usually an animation, but will stop all further processes that come after the current one. Other processes will never start.
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"
// Enter JQuery command here. The event object is passed in as "ev"

With the 'Custom action' Rapid will read your code and will generate content based on what has been written. This action type takes a jQuery method. This action type is recommended for more advanced programmers.
Click here to display a message

[{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C40_","text":"Showing and hiding controls can be a very important aspect in relation to the type of Rapid application you're making. A few examples of making use of this action would be to hide controls based on a user's actions, and keeping controls hidden until they are needed. By default Rapid will have everything on the page set to being shown.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C41_","text":"This type of toggle for controls can be useful for displaying and hiding other controls on your page, but in a more restricted way. For example, a good use of the toggle action is to attach it to a radio button. One option can show some controls and the other option can hide those controls.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C42_","text":"Sliding controls up and down can provide your app with a more stylistic way of making controls show and hide. Here these are done with two separate buttons, one for sliding up and another for sliding down.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C144_","text":"The slide toggle is a more stylistic version of the show/hide toggle shown above. The same rules apply for the normal slide actions, being able to set a duration, but useful ways to use the toggle is described in other toggle hints.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C165_","text":"Fading controls in and out is another stylistic way of showing and hiding different controls in your Rapid application. Additional ways in which to use this effectively are included in previous hints.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C197_","text":"Like with the other toggles available, this toggle will fade controls in and out with each activation. Effective ways in which to make use of this are included in other hints.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C209_","text":"Putting the focus on certain controls can be very handy in combination with validation. If a person fails validation when pressing the appropriate button then they can be guided to the control that needs correcting.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C222_","text":"A good example of making use of changing controls to read-only would be when reviewing information that has already been filled out in a Rapid form application. These read-only controls will not be able to be altered in any way, meaning the information provided will remain unchanged.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C234_","text":"Adding and removing style classes can be a useful way of showcasing different styles that you have created, in Rapid Admin's Appearance tab, or for cycling through the Themes' style classes that come with Rapid.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C247_","text":"Similar to the above, this can be used in the same way. Classes can be cycled on and off using the class toggle action.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C259_","text":"Due to being able to remove all child classes, this can be useful for a number of different reasons. A good example would be to remove styling from a group of controls in your app based on user input. These controls can have one style when being initially set on page load and another for when a user interacts in a certain way with your application.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C269_","text":"By showing a page as a dialogue you can keep users on the same page, running in the background, whilst allowing them to have access to a second page over the top of the first. In order to show a page as a dialogue you first need to have a navigation action that leads to another page, which can then be shown as a dialogue through a checkbox.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C281_","text":"This is a lesser used action that functions with Databases and Webservices. By default an error will be shown if no error action is set. This error is overwritten when an error action is set, because Rapid now assumes you know what you are doing, and has no need to fill in the gaps.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C295_","text":"It is more adviced to use this in conjunction with animations, however you can also use this with other Rapid actions on your application. clearQueue can be particularly useful if you want to attract attention to a particular area of your app but wish for animations to cease when a user moves their cursor into the specified area.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C303_","text":"As mentioned, this is recommended for advanced programmers. It is possible to experiment with different jQuery methods, even simple ones like the example included here, however it is most useful for complex jQuery that can really make your Rapid app pop out.","type":"hover"}]

{"controlHints":[{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C40_","text":"Showing and hiding controls can be a very important aspect in relation to the type of Rapid application you're making. A few examples of making use of this action would be to hide controls based on a user's actions, and keeping controls hidden until they are needed. By default Rapid will have everything on the page set to being shown.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C41_","text":"This type of toggle for controls can be useful for displaying and hiding other controls on your page, but in a more restricted way. For example, a good use of the toggle action is to attach it to a radio button. One option can show some controls and the other option can hide those controls.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C42_","text":"Sliding controls up and down can provide your app with a more stylistic way of making controls show and hide. Here these are done with two separate buttons, one for sliding up and another for sliding down.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C144_","text":"The slide toggle is a more stylistic version of the show/hide toggle shown above. The same rules apply for the normal slide actions, being able to set a duration, but useful ways to use the toggle is described in other toggle hints.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C165_","text":"Fading controls in and out is another stylistic way of showing and hiding different controls in your Rapid application. Additional ways in which to use this effectively are included in previous hints.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C197_","text":"Like with the other toggles available, this toggle will fade controls in and out with each activation. Effective ways in which to make use of this are included in other hints.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C209_","text":"Putting the focus on certain controls can be very handy in combination with validation. If a person fails validation when pressing the appropriate button then they can be guided to the control that needs correcting.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C222_","text":"A good example of making use of changing controls to read-only would be when reviewing information that has already been filled out in a Rapid form application. These read-only controls will not be able to be altered in any way, meaning the information provided will remain unchanged.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C234_","text":"Adding and removing style classes can be a useful way of showcasing different styles that you have created, in Rapid Admin's Appearance tab, or for cycling through the Themes' style classes that come with Rapid.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C247_","text":"Similar to the above, this can be used in the same way. Classes can be cycled on and off using the class toggle action.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C259_","text":"Due to being able to remove all child classes, this can be useful for a number of different reasons. A good example would be to remove styling from a group of controls in your app based on user input. These controls can have one style when being initially set on page load and another for when a user interacts in a certain way with your application.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C269_","text":"By showing a page as a dialogue you can keep users on the same page, running in the background, whilst allowing them to have access to a second page over the top of the first. In order to show a page as a dialogue you first need to have a navigation action that leads to another page, which can then be shown as a dialogue through a checkbox.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C281_","text":"This is a lesser used action that functions with Databases and Webservices. By default an error will be shown if no error action is set. This error is overwritten when an error action is set, because Rapid now assumes you know what you are doing, and has no need to fill in the gaps.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C295_","text":"It is more adviced to use this in conjunction with animations, however you can also use this with other Rapid actions on your application. clearQueue can be particularly useful if you want to attract attention to a particular area of your app but wish for animations to cease when a user moves their cursor into the specified area.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width:400px;","controlId":"P1_C303_","text":"As mentioned, this is recommended for advanced programmers. It is possible to experiment with different jQuery methods, even simple ones like the example included here, however it is most useful for complex jQuery that can really make your Rapid app pop out.","type":"hover"}]}

page.htmlBody:
This page will detail the different actions available in Rapid. We will be covering many concepts with actions, but for this page we are focussing on buttons. Each be accompanied by a hint that explains in greater detail what each button does and some more details on how to use the actions.

Pressing the 'Hide' button will hide the image and pressing the 'Show' button will reveal the image again.
Pressing this button will trigger the image on the right to show and hide itself, using a single button.
Pressing the two buttons will slide the text below into view or out of view.
This text will disappear when the above buttons are pressed.
Pressing this button will cause the text below to show and hide itself, with a single button.
This text will disappear when the above button is pressed.
Pressing the 'Fade out' button will fade the image out over time and pressing the 'Fade in' button will reveal the image again.
Similar to the above, this button will fade the image in and out based on the current state of the image.
Pressing the button will put the focus on the input box to the right.
The 'Disable input' button will disable the input to the right, putting it into read-only mode. The 'Enable input' button will re-enable the input box.
The 'Add class' button will apply a Rapid theme style class to the button on the right. The 'Remove class' button will remove this class.
As with other toggle features in Rapid, the 'Toggle class' button will apply a Rapid theme style class to the button on the right, or remove it, based on the current state of the control.
Removes the child classes that are attached to the 'Sample' button on the right. In this case the 'Sample' button is contained within a panel, classed as a parent control. Removing the style classes in this way will clear up any added features to all child controls within the parent.
Pressing the 'Show dialogue' button will display a dialogue. Dialogues are additional pages that you make in Rapid and then navigate to them.
A more specialist action, the showError action is used to display a default error message if it has been overwritten with anything else in an error action. In the event you want this default error message again then you can use the showError action to have it display once more.
Activating the clearQueue action will carry out the current process, usually an animation, but will stop all further processes that come after the current one. Other processes will never start.
With the 'Custom action' Rapid will read your code and will generate content based on what has been written. This action type takes a jQuery method. This action type is recommended for more advanced programmers.
Click here to display a message
page.name: 02_controlActions

rolesHtml.html:
This page will detail the different actions available in Rapid. We will be covering many concepts with actions, but for this page we are focussing on buttons. Each be accompanied by a hint that explains in greater detail what each button does and some more details on how to use the actions.

Pressing the 'Hide' button will hide the image and pressing the 'Show' button will reveal the image again.
Pressing this button will trigger the image on the right to show and hide itself, using a single button.
Pressing the two buttons will slide the text below into view or out of view.
This text will disappear when the above buttons are pressed.
Pressing this button will cause the text below to show and hide itself, with a single button.
This text will disappear when the above button is pressed.
Pressing the 'Fade out' button will fade the image out over time and pressing the 'Fade in' button will reveal the image again.
Similar to the above, this button will fade the image in and out based on the current state of the image.
Pressing the button will put the focus on the input box to the right.
The 'Disable input' button will disable the input to the right, putting it into read-only mode. The 'Enable input' button will re-enable the input box.
The 'Add class' button will apply a Rapid theme style class to the button on the right. The 'Remove class' button will remove this class.
As with other toggle features in Rapid, the 'Toggle class' button will apply a Rapid theme style class to the button on the right, or remove it, based on the current state of the control.
Removes the child classes that are attached to the 'Sample' button on the right. In this case the 'Sample' button is contained within a panel, classed as a parent control. Removing the style classes in this way will clear up any added features to all child controls within the parent.
Pressing the 'Show dialogue' button will display a dialogue. Dialogues are additional pages that you make in Rapid and then navigate to them.
A more specialist action, the showError action is used to display a default error message if it has been overwritten with anything else in an error action. In the event you want this default error message again then you can use the showError action to have it display once more.
Activating the clearQueue action will carry out the current process, usually an animation, but will stop all further processes that come after the current one. Other processes will never start.
With the 'Custom action' Rapid will read your code and will generate content based on what has been written. This action type takes a jQuery method. This action type is recommended for more advanced programmers.
Click here to display a message

page.title: Control actions
